title: Raging wildfires force 100,000 people to flee homes in California
text:
Some 100,000 people have been evacuated as firefighters battle a series of blazes throughout California (Picture: Getty)

Almost two million people were left without power as wildfires continue to tear through California.

Some 100,000 people had to evacuate their homes as deadly blazes rage on the outskirts of Los Angeles.

The fires erupted on Thursday along the northern tier of the San Fernando Valley and are being whipped up by the powerful Santa Ana winds.

The Los Angeles Fire Department said dozens of homes have been destroyed in the last few days and there are two confirmed deaths so far.

By Saturday morning, the fires were only 13% contained.

Some 100,000 people in 20,000 homes are subject to mandatory evacuation orders.

Ozzy Butler pours water on to his deck at his parents house as the Saddleridge Fire burns along Thunderbird Avenue in Porter Ranch (Picture: Getty)

Spitting embers are causing more blazes to erupt (Picture: Getty)

Firefighters work at a house fire after dawn during the Saddleridge fire (Picture: Getty)

Fire swept down the hill, spitting embers at the LA home of Edwin Bernard, 73.

He said he and his wife scrambled to go, leaving medication, photo albums and their four cats.

He recalled: ‘It was a whole curtain of fire. There was fire on all sides. We had to leave.’

A middle-aged man who was nearby suffered a heart attack and died, while a death was also confirmed at an earlier wildfire east of Los Angeles.

Residents at a mobile home park in Calimesa, 75 miles east of downtown LA, say they are concerned for Lois Arvickson.

The 89-year-old resident is feared to have died when her home burnt down.

Her son Don Turner said she called him to say she was evacuating.

‘She said she’s getting her purse and she’s getting out. And then the line went dead,’ Mr Turner said.

That fire was sparked after a rubbish truck dumped a smouldering load, causing dry grass to quickly ignite.

Jonathan Stahl helped rescue his grandmother and aunt from their home.

Speaking from an evacuation centre, he said: ‘We just packed up what we could as fast as we could.

‘If we had stuck around we would have been in trouble, real big trouble.’

Firefighters work at a house fire in the early morning hours (Picture: Getty)

Flames heat up high power lines and two million were left without electricity (Picture: Getty)

Firefighters tackle a blaze at a home (Picture: Getty)

The fire at the mobile home park destroyed 74 buildings there. It then spread to nearby areas, carried by the 50mph winds.

Fire chief Ralph Terrazas said: ‘As you can imagine the embers from the wind have been travelling a significant distance, which causes another fire to start.’

LA Mayor Eric Garcetti added: ‘It’s not the fire itself but the danger of wind taking an ember, blowing it someplace, and seeing entire neighbourhoods overnight get lit.’

Helicopters and planes are flying around the LA area making repeated drops of water while around 1,000 firefighters are on the ground.

There are also around 450 police officers on the ground and officials have said they will have ‘no tolerance’ for looters.

Those under mandatory evacuation orders packed shelters and police allowed some to return home for five minutes on Friday to collect their belongings.

Mr Terrazas said he had seen ‘hundreds if not thousands of homes’ with charred backyards where firefighters just managed to stop a full-scale blaze.

Flames heat up high power lines (Picture: Getty)

A private collection of 30 classic cars burned in Granada Hills, San Fernando Valley (Picture: Rex)

Experts say there will be more fires in California because of climate change (Picture: Getty)

Fire officials have warned that they expect more intense and devastating California wildfires due, in part, to climate change.

They often follow typically dry summer and early autumn and are whipped up by the Santa Ana winds, which bring a dangerous mix of low humidity levels and powerful gusts.

The National Weather Service has warned of extreme fire danger in Southern California areas.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company switched off power for millions of residents in a bid to stop their equipment sparking even more deadly fires.

It is not known what caused the first fire to start, which triggered the subsequent blazes.

However arson investigators said a witness reported seeing sparks or flames coming from a power line near to where it is believed to have started.
